issue.title: Unsigned integers should be avoided in the User API

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or an improvement of an existing feature

issue.body:
### Problem Description

I have had an issue where a polars operation created a `uint` column, I then passed that column to another library and got a surprising (overflow) result. As a user I can cast the `uint` to `int`, but this is most likely after some debugging.

Here is some exploration showing how easy it can be to err when working with a `uint` but expecting `int` behaviour.

```python
>>> import polars as pl
>>> n = 3
>>> s = pl.Series(range(n))
>>> ranks = s.rank(method='min')  # creates a uint32 series
>>> ranks
shape: (3,)
Series: '' [u32]
[
        1
        2
        3
]
>>> ranks[0] - ranks[-1]  # good, because indexing into a pl.Series[uint32] returns an int
-2
>>> -ranks  # bad
shape: (3,)
Series: '' [u32]
[
        4294967295
        4294967294
        4294967293
]
>>> ranks[::-1].diff()  # bad
shape: (3,)
Series: '' [u32]
[
        null
        4294967295
        4294967295
]
>>> [r - n for r in ranks] # good, because iterating over a pl.Series[uint32] yields ints
[-2, -1, 0]
>>> ranks - n  # bad, and inconsistent with above
shape: (3,)
Series: '' [u32]
[
        4294967294
        4294967295
        0
]

```

I think in the userspace `uint` dtypes should be strictly opt-in.

Elsewhere on unsigned integers:

1. https://wesmckinney.com/blog/avoid-unsigned-integers/
2. https://google.github.io/styleguide/cppguide.html#Integer_Types
3. https://hamstergene.github.io/posts/2021-10-30-do-not-use-unsigned-for-nonnegativity/

issue.title: Unsigned integers should be avoided in the User API

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or an improvement of an existing feature

issue.body:
### Problem Description

I have had an issue where a polars operation created a `uint` column, I then passed that column to another library and got a surprising (overflow) result. As a user I can cast the `uint` to `int`, but this is most likely after some debugging.

Here is some exploration showing how easy it can be to err when working with a `uint` but expecting `int` behaviour.

```python
>>> import polars as pl
>>> n = 3
>>> s = pl.Series(range(n))
>>> ranks = s.rank(method='min')  # creates a uint32 series
>>> ranks
shape: (3,)
Series: '' [u32]
[
        1
        2
        3
]
>>> ranks[0] - ranks[-1]  # good, because indexing into a pl.Series[uint32] returns an int
-2
>>> -ranks  # bad
shape: (3,)
Series: '' [u32]
[
        4294967295
        4294967294
        4294967293
]
>>> ranks[::-1].diff()  # bad
shape: (3,)
Series: '' [u32]
[
        null
        4294967295
        4294967295
]
>>> [r - n for r in ranks] # good, because iterating over a pl.Series[uint32] yields ints
[-2, -1, 0]
>>> ranks - n  # bad, and inconsistent with above
shape: (3,)
Series: '' [u32]
[
        4294967294
        4294967295
        0
]

```

I think in the userspace `uint` dtypes should be strictly opt-in.

Elsewhere on unsigned integers:

1. https://wesmckinney.com/blog/avoid-unsigned-integers/
2. https://google.github.io/styleguide/cppguide.html#Integer_Types
3. https://hamstergene.github.io/posts/2021-10-30-do-not-use-unsigned-for-nonnegativity/

comment.body: I think it's safe to say that we are going to keep using unsigned integers where appropriate. I'll close this for now.

pull_request.title: feat(rust, python): expressify `offset` and `length` parameters for `str.slice`
pull_request.body:
Attempts to resolve #10890

I see it had been previously self-assigned @orlp - hopefully I'm not intruding here. 

(I imagine you had more important things to work on.)

```python
df = pl.DataFrame({
   "foo": ["abcde", "fghijk"],
   "offset": [1, 2],
   "length": [3, 4],
})

df.with_columns(slice = pl.col("foo").str.slice("offset", "length"))

# shape: (2, 4)
# ┌────────┬────────┬────────┬───────┐
# │ foo    ┆ offset ┆ length ┆ slice │
# │ ---    ┆ ---    ┆ ---    ┆ ---   │
# │ str    ┆ i64    ┆ i64    ┆ str   │
# ╞════════╪════════╪════════╪═══════╡
# │ abcde  ┆ 1      ┆ 3      ┆ bcd   │
# │ fghijk ┆ 2      ┆ 4      ┆ hijk  │
# └────────┴────────┴────────┴───────┘
```

I used the `strip_prefix` impl as a guide/template https://github.com/pola-rs/polars/blob/main/crates/polars-ops/src/chunked_array/strings/strip.rs 

Some things I'm not sure about if anybody wants to give feedback:

- Instead of all the length checks, I just broadcasted `offset` and  `length` using `.clear().extend_constant()` - is this an acceptable approach or is it a bad idea + performance concern?
- Is there a way to "typecheck" the params, or is it okay to just `.cast()`?
- Is `UInt64` the correct type for `length`?
- The param name is `offset` but internally `start` is used, I changed everything to `offset`, is this the right approach?
- I had to modify `polars-sql` as it used `.slice()` (incidentally, that uses `start` as the param name, should it be `start` everywhere instead of `offset`?)
- Is it okay to use `!matches!`?
- As `length` is a param name, I had to re-jig the error format a bit to avoid ending up with `length value length`.

issue.title: Add support to read and write Amazon ION files

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or an improvement of an existing feature

issue.body:
### Description

Hi!

We heavily rely on [Amazon ION](https://github.com/amazon-ion/ion-python) file format. It would be great to add support for ION in polars using `read_ion` and `write_ion` methods. Here is a reproducer of a workaround we do for now:

 ```python
import requests
import polars as pl
import amazon.ion.simpleion as ion
from amazon.ion.simple_types import IonPyDecimal, IonPyNull


def convert_ion_types(value):
    if isinstance(value, IonPyNull):
        return None
    elif isinstance(value, IonPyDecimal):
        return float(value)
    else:
        return value


url = "https://huggingface.co/datasets/kestra/datasets/resolve/main/ion/employees.ion"
response = requests.get(url)
response.raise_for_status()
ion_content = response.content
ion_data = ion.loads(ion_content, single_value=False)
list_of_dicts = [dict(record) for record in ion_data]
list_of_dicts = [
    {k: convert_ion_types(v) for k, v in record.items()} for record in list_of_dicts
]

polars_df = pl.DataFrame(list_of_dicts)
print(polars_df.glimpse())
```

It would be fantastic to support it directly:

```python
import polars as pl
df = pl.read_ion("/path/to/file.ion") 
print(df.glimpse())
```

issue.title: Reorder columns using ellipsis

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or an improvement of an existing feature

issue.body:
### Description

Reordering columns is sometimes very useful, but need some extra code in Polars and other Data Frame libraries for just 2 or 3 columns.
But using Ellipsis make it easy and tricky for many usages...
```
df = pl.DataFrame(schema=dict(
    fname=pl.Utf8,
    lname=pl.Utf8,
    age=pl.UInt8,
    favColor = pl.Utf8,
    money = pl.Decimal,
    workhour = pl.Float64,
))
df.select(pl.col(['lname', 'workhour', ...]))
```
Means lname and workhour columns must be at first and others be next to them. Or we can also use [..., 'lname', 'workhour'], but it is less usable in my opinion. It is a tricky but pythonic way for reordering.

issue.title: fix(python,rust): str.concat on empty list
issue.body:
aggregation methods should always return a single value, otherwise it can lead to unexpected behavior and bugs (e.g. #12053)

current behavior:
- empty list: return Series of shape (0,) >>>>> this is the bug
- otherwise: return Series of shape (1,) with the concatenated/joined string

PR:
- always return Series of shape (1,) with the concatenated/joined string
- if empty list, return empty string (as discussed here:https://github.com/pola-rs/polars/issues/10814#issuecomment-1700971115)

```python
pl.Series([], dtype=pl.Utf8).str.concat()

# OLD
shape: (0,)
Series: '' [str]
[
]

# NEW
shape: (1,)
Series: '' [str]
[
	""
]
```

Note: this does not address the issue of skipping nulls (#10814) but only fixes the bug for empty lists

comment.body: @reswqa I would greenlight implementation with `ignore` and `propagate`, with `ignore` as the default. We can always add a `raise` option later if we do change our mind.

issue.title: Rounding to significant figures

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or an improvement of an existing feature

issue.body:
### Description

Recently I have been working on a project where we needed to round to significant figures and realised there is no way to do this in pandas, numpy or polars. I found [this](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/18915378/rounding-to-significant-figures-in-numpy/59888924#59888924) as the best solution.

```
def signif(x, p):
    x = np.asarray(x)
    x_positive = np.where(np.isfinite(x) & (x != 0), np.abs(x), 10**(p-1))
    mags = 10 ** (p - 1 - np.floor(np.log10(x_positive)))
    return np.round(x * mags) / mags
```

However it would be nice to have it as part of a package. Would it be possible to include this? 

I have implemented this already here #11959 which is about 20% faster than the numpy one here already. However I can imagine there is a better way than using the zip_with maybe? 

Thank you!

comment.body:
@owrior

I had a discussion with @stinodego and I believe we settled on adding this functionality, but as a separate function named `round_sig_figs`.

PR:


comment.body:
> I will take a look at the remaining issue of skipping nulls.

If you work on this you should probably look into here #6919 
I wrote a small summary of the problem and ritchie also said:
> I would accept a PR with "ignore" and "raise" as null_behavior arguments.

So I think the goal is to either "ignore" or "raise" if nulls occur (current problem is that they appear as `null` in text form :D)

issue.title: is_between incorrect behaviour with unsigned integers
issue.body:
### Checks

- [X] I have checked that this issue has not already been reported.

- [X] I have confirmed this bug exists on the [latest version](https://pypi.org/project/polars/) of Polars.


### Reproducible example

```python

import polars as pl
data = {"col1": [0, 2], "col2": [2, 4]}
df2 = pl.DataFrame(data, schema={"col1": pl.Int32, "col2": pl.UInt32})
df3 = pl.DataFrame(data, schema={"col1": pl.Int32, "col2": pl.UInt32})
df_joined = df2.join(df3, on="col1", how="left")

df_joined.filter(pl.col.col2_right.is_between(pl.col.col2 - 1, pl.col.col2)) # 2 rows, all good
df_joined.filter(pl.col.col2_right.is_between(pl.col.col2 - 2, pl.col.col2)) # 2 rows, all good
df_joined.filter(pl.col.col2_right.is_between(pl.col.col2 - 3, pl.col.col2)) # Looser restriction, 1 row!
df_joined.filter(pl.col.col2_right.is_between(pl.col.col2 - 4, pl.col.col2)) # Looser restriction, 1 row!
df_joined.filter(pl.col.col2_right.is_between(pl.col.col2 - 5, pl.col.col2)) # Looser restriction, No rows!


```


### Log output

_No response_

### Issue description

When the lower restriction of the is_between goes below 0 it doesn't return rows that it should (see example).

### Expected behavior

All examples in this example should return 2 rows.

### Installed versions

<details>

```
--------Version info---------
Polars:              0.19.8
Index type:          UInt32
Platform:            Windows-10-10.0.22621-SP0
Python:              3.11.4 (tags/v3.11.4:d2340ef, Jun  7 2023, 05:45:37) [MSC v.1934 64 bit (AMD64)]

----Optional dependencies----
adbc_driver_sqlite:  <not installed>
cloudpickle:         3.0.0
connectorx:          <not installed>
deltalake:           <not installed>
fsspec:              2023.9.2
gevent:              <not installed>
matplotlib:          3.8.0
numpy:               1.26.0
openpyxl:            <not installed>
pandas:              2.1.1
pyarrow:             13.0.0
pydantic:            <not installed>
pyiceberg:           <not installed>
pyxlsb:              <not installed>
sqlalchemy:          <not installed>
xlsx2csv:            <not installed>
xlsxwriter:          <not installed>
```

</details>

issue.title: Replacing empty string does not work as expected
issue.body:
### Checks

- [X] I have checked that this issue has not already been reported.

- [X] I have confirmed this bug exists on the [latest version](https://pypi.org/project/polars/) of Polars.


### Reproducible example

```python
import polars as pl

df = pl.DataFrame({"test": ["A", "B", "", "C"]})
df = df.with_columns(pl.col("test").str.replace("", "n.a.", literal=True))
df.head()
```


### Log output

```shell
shape: (4, 1)
test
str
"n.a.A"
"n.a.B"
"n.a."
"n.a.C"
```


### Issue description

Instead of replacing empty strings with the replacement value it adds the replacement value to the beginning of every string in that column.

### Expected behavior

```shell
shape: (4, 1)
test
str
"A"
"B"
"n.a."
"C"
```

### Installed versions

<details>

```
--------Version info---------
Polars:              0.19.11
Index type:          UInt32
Platform:            Windows-11-10.0.22621-SP0
Python:              3.12.0 (tags/v3.12.0:0fb18b0, Oct  2 2023, 13:03:39) [MSC v.1935 64 bit (AMD64)]

----Optional dependencies----
adbc_driver_sqlite:  <not installed>
cloudpickle:         <not installed>
connectorx:          <not installed>
deltalake:           <not installed>
fsspec:              <not installed>
gevent:              <not installed>
matplotlib:          <not installed>
numpy:               1.26.1
openpyxl:            3.1.2
pandas:              2.1.1
pyarrow:             <not installed>
pydantic:            <not installed>
pyiceberg:           <not installed>
pyxlsb:              <not installed>
sqlalchemy:          <not installed>
xlsx2csv:            0.8.1
xlsxwriter:          3.1.9
```

</details>

comment.body:
If you need a working implementation right now I would use and prefer `.map_dict` if I want to change complete strings instead of parts of a string
```python
df.with_columns(
    mapped=pl.col("test").map_dict(
        {"": "n.a."},
        default=pl.first(),
    ),
)

┌──────┬────────┐
│ test ┆ mapped │
│ ---  ┆ ---    │
│ str  ┆ str    │
╞══════╪════════╡
│ A    ┆ A      │
│ B    ┆ B      │
│      ┆ n.a.   │
│ C    ┆ C      │
└──────┴────────┘
```

issue.title: `from_pandas` incorrectly handles object columns in some cases
issue.body:
### Problem description

I use polars 0.19.1 and Python 3.11.5.

I have a script that takes a query, loads that into a pandas dataframe, convert to a polars dataframe and then check if any column contains a specific value and returns those columns for data quality checks.

In this case I load data via SQL query into a pandas dataframe (library only supports an "export_to_pandas" function).

`df = c.export_to_pandas('''SELECT * FROM t''')`

This dataframe has a column `A` which contains numbers in the beginning but also values like "D - 12345".
In the pandas dataframe this column has type "object".

When I try to convert this dataframe to polars via
`df = pl.from_pandas(df)`

this results in a
> ArrowInvalid: Could not convert '58708' with type str: tried to convert to int64

because apparently polars scans the first N rows, sees only numbers and some NULL values and decides that this column is int64 but then it fails because "D - 12345" is no int64 and the column should stay "object" / "Utf8".

I don't see any way in https://pola-rs.github.io/polars/py-polars/html/reference/api/polars.from_pandas.html to use something like "infer_schema_length" like stated in https://github.com/pola-rs/polars/issues/4489 (but it seems this did not cover the `from_pandas` function) and be able to set it to max because the query changes everytime and I can't hardcode anything.

comment.body:
> So we have to find a solution of handling multiple datatypes within a series.

But the column already has a datatype in pandas, where polars is reading from?
`In the pandas dataframe this column has type "object".`

issue.title: Replacing empty string does not work as expected
issue.body:
### Checks

- [X] I have checked that this issue has not already been reported.

- [X] I have confirmed this bug exists on the [latest version](https://pypi.org/project/polars/) of Polars.


### Reproducible example

```python
import polars as pl

df = pl.DataFrame({"test": ["A", "B", "", "C"]})
df = df.with_columns(pl.col("test").str.replace("", "n.a.", literal=True))
df.head()
```


### Log output

```shell
shape: (4, 1)
test
str
"n.a.A"
"n.a.B"
"n.a."
"n.a.C"
```


### Issue description

Instead of replacing empty strings with the replacement value it adds the replacement value to the beginning of every string in that column.

### Expected behavior

```shell
shape: (4, 1)
test
str
"A"
"B"
"n.a."
"C"
```

### Installed versions

<details>

```
--------Version info---------
Polars:              0.19.11
Index type:          UInt32
Platform:            Windows-11-10.0.22621-SP0
Python:              3.12.0 (tags/v3.12.0:0fb18b0, Oct  2 2023, 13:03:39) [MSC v.1935 64 bit (AMD64)]

----Optional dependencies----
adbc_driver_sqlite:  <not installed>
cloudpickle:         <not installed>
connectorx:          <not installed>
deltalake:           <not installed>
fsspec:              <not installed>
gevent:              <not installed>
matplotlib:          <not installed>
numpy:               1.26.1
openpyxl:            3.1.2
pandas:              2.1.1
pyarrow:             <not installed>
pydantic:            <not installed>
pyiceberg:           <not installed>
pyxlsb:              <not installed>
sqlalchemy:          <not installed>
xlsx2csv:            0.8.1
xlsxwriter:          3.1.9
```

</details>

comment.body:
Just adding a simpler repro for display purposes:
```python
pl.select(pl.lit("bar").str.replace("", "foo"))
# shape: (1, 1)
# ┌─────────┐
# │ literal │
# │ ---     │
# │ str     │
# ╞═════════╡
# │ foobar  │
# └─────────┘
```
